This is a ghost figurine. I have included the original Rhino file as well as several versions of the files (different face counts). There are two different models of ghost, one has a \\"tail\\" and the other does not. The ghosts pictured were printed with Blue UV happy PLA from UltiMachine (http://ultimachine.com/content/pla-blue-translucent-5lb) and would be very cool printed in Makerbot\'s glow-in-the-dark ABS (http://store.makerbot.com/plastic/glow-abs-plastic-1lb.html).

The \\"SuperReduced\\" versions are the best for 3D printing as they have the lowest face count.  The numbers at the end indicate scale (50 is 50%, 70 is 70%).  I have included the other versions in case someone want to try to print a higher resolution version.

comments.text: UV light definitely makes it look really cool!

A speedy-made replacement for a car remote key, which happen to break quite often.
Compatible with part #9166199, fits older volvo remotes without a panic button (Who needs panic?).
I made it in sketchup as a test case, can be improved a lot.

I modeled and tested it for printing it on a Cube (cubify.com) with ABS. Print without raft and supports. Then put in the original remote (including buttons) and battery and use a M2 self-tapping screw to fix.
In my case, some postprocessing is necessary due to the Cube's inaccuracies.

title: Plexiglas enclosure for the up! plus / Afinia 3d printer

description.text: Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39019 This is a plexiglas enclosure for the up! plus/afinia 3d printer that will keep your print warm and safe. I made this derivative so I can lasercut it in 10 minutes instead of printing it for 20 hours. Like the initial one, it keeps the electronic and extuder outside the heat retention chamber. The design can probably be refined to keep the rear step motor outside as well.

• the file (you can choose .ai,, .pdf or .svg) is designed for a 60x90cm sheet of 3mm plexiglass.
  • No glue required, you can use de screw on the side of the printer to hold the side panels, the other panels are just clipped.
  • you can remove the tops, front and back panels for easy access to the build volume.
  • The panel around the extruder can be coverer with a thin sheet of transparent paper cut and attached around the extruder so that it keep the warm air inside.
  • FilamentHolder.stl will nicely fit on the side panel and support the filament guide.
  • I use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26659 as spool holder.
  • You will need slightly longer m2.5 screws as the original ones are just a tad short to support the extra depth from the plexiglas.
    • If you want me to lasercut it for you, write me at [email protected]
    Better yet: if you live around Brussels, check www.realizeBxl.be and come make it yourself :o)

comments.text: 3DPrintClean is developing an Odor and Ultrafine Particle filtration attachment for DIY enclosures. Would make a great addition. See http://3dprintclean.com/3dprintclean-scrubber.htm - Disclosure, I am the founder of 3DPrintClean.

title: QU-BD Two-Up Replacement Part QQ 12-HTD3-05 Aluminum Pulley

description.text:
My QU-BD Two-Up printer came without these two important X / Y axis timing pulleys. These are part QQ - 12-HTD3-05.
So I figured a temporary replacement could be made while I wait 3 weeks for them to ship me the original bits.
This was made from droftart's excellent timing gear generator SCAD file, here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627
My modifications to the SCAD file include adding a key to lock it to the spindle shaft. My first upload of this file used bolts to lock it against the shaft, but there were clearance issues when assembling the Two Up, so I added the keyed shaft and superglued it to the motor spindle. It now works very well, holding up as well as the original parts and allowing no slack or play when changing direction.
Pulley specs are:
12 Tooth Pulley
6mm Belt Width
3mm Spacing HTD Tooth Profile
5mm Bore Diameter (For NEMA 17 Motors)
Flange on both ends to ensure belt doesn't slip off.

comments.text: Given this was 3 years ago, any update on the performance? Are these still holding up?
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: I used mine for a few months until the real part came. Wear was negligible, but my part was printed with nylon filament at the highest detail possible. I wouldn't use it for the long haul personally, but it gets you by in a pinch and had no issues working and contributed no quality issues in and of itself.
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Thanks for the heads up. One of my metal pulleys has a bent lip. Doesn't effect it's performance any, just my OCD while it runs. I was hoping something printed would last, but I guess I'll just order a replacement.
comments.author: QB89Dragon

comments.text: YOU ARE AMAZING!!!!! I have been waiting for 6 weeks so far for the pullys as the company did not send me them as well, along with multiple nuts and bolts which I will have to go buy, as I dont believe they will ever send to me, even though I have talked to them 3 times and all 3 times they say there sending them that day. You are seriously a life saver and made my day!!! Ill have my buddy print these tonight for me so i can get the printer working!!! Thanks again!
comments.author: nconsola

comments.text:
Glad to be of help. These plastic ones seem to be working great so far - been using my printer all week and so far have no indication that the quality will be any better with the metal ones when they finally arrive.
Be sure to do one of the x gantry sag fixes on your new printer, such as the one with pulleys - home depot screen door pulleys work well for this.

title: Slim Bowden E3D v5 mount for Prusa i3 with fan shroud and LED ring

description.text:
Get the maximum Z and X height as well as less vibration in Z direction due to the compact design. The spotlight provided by the LED ring really helps to see the print clearer. Mounts E3D v5 with Ø25mm heat sink and a standard Prusa i3 x-carriage with 30mm hole distance. The 30mm fan is recessed for compactness, and the open right side allows heat to escape from the heat sink. The heat sink snaps in place pretty securely without additional support. I made an optional clamp can be screwed in. Also allows for 40mm LED ring which can be glued/screwed to the recessed area on the bottom.
http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2050601.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.X40+mm+led+ring&_nkw=40+mm+led+ring&_sacat=0
http://droopas.blogspot.com

Print with ABS or PLA with ~30% infill. Use support ("Touching buildplate" if using Cura).
0.4mm nozzle
0.2mm layer height Snap in your hot end and a 30mm fan.
Secure the mount to the x-carriage with M3 bolts and nuts.

description.text:
The iPod cases I downloaded and tried where not fitting right in my son's iPod so I did this. The patterns I used here can be downloaded in thingiverse.com/thing:33359 and thingiverse.com/thing:22568 This thing's OpenSCAD is too dirt and messy to upload it, sorry, just let me know if you would like to risk a headache and I may include it "as is". For the logo I used a flatbed scanner and Inkscape to get a couple of DXF that are then used as shown in the OpenSCAD available for download. Update Aug. 03 2013:
Uploaded a few test STL to allow a quick print and check and prevent having to waste time and material printing something that doesn't fit right. Thanks a lot to FherraZ for pointing this out!

Single Extruder Only:
  • iP4_case.stl
  • iP4_gCarved.stl
    • Dual Extruder Only:
  • iP4_gCarvedDual_Case.stl & iP4_gCarvedDual_Top.stl
    • Single or Dual Extruder:
    (use the 1st STL for single extrusion or combine it with the 2nd STL for dual)
  • iP4_zCase.stl & iP4_zStripes.stl
  • iP4_gCase_nnn.stl & iP4_gSpots_nnn.stl
    • For the last ones (gCase & gSpots) "nnn" is the thickness of the lines (150 = 1.50 mm) and must be the same number for the two files being merged into one build. Test STLs for fit check and scaling factor:
    "test_edges.stl" and "test_corners.stl" may be tricky and are not "the best choice" to take measurements and determine the scaling factor. However, when using them onto a flat surface, they give a very good idea about the fit. On my tests, "test_cap.stl" fits slightly tigh in the top of the device and slightly losse in the bottom (I just don't get why but it's like that) "test_side.stl" fits just that little bit loose however, there's no noticeable play so it's fine. To determine the scaling factor you'll need to measure one of the test STL files, "guess" how much bigger or smaller it shoud be and use as scaling factor the result of:
    (your meaurement + or - amount) / your measurement IMO, the best measurement can be done for the outer width of the case close to the corners, the average size in a set of 12 that I've print is 62.68mm, say 62.7mm. This same measurement in the "test_cap.STL" shows a value close to 62.4mm. Good luck!

comments.author: aymiusa

comments.text: I assume (forgive me if I'm wrong) that you are printing this in PLA and quick/coarse settings/profile (layer height >= 0.30mm). I don't remember how thick I designed the top layers that should hold the "tiles" but you should get at least 2 solid layers. The extruder temperature should also be high enough to ensure that that each layer bonds well with the previous one and low enough to be able to remove the raft easily. Btw, I never use a raft. I printed mine in ABS on kapton, blue painter's tape should do the trick for PLA. Talking about materials, tolerances (for ABS) are quite small and PLA may not be flexible enough and break when inserting the iPod into this thing. I hope you can get around the issues you're finding with this and we see another "made" popping up in the makes section. Good luck and thank you for giving this thing a try!
comments.author: aymiusa

comments.text: Wow! Thank you for responding so quickly! I'm a major 3D printing newbie--your case was actually my first print!--and so I didn't even understand a lot of this. I think my main issue was that I only printed one file and didn't put both together like I was supposed to (sorry!), hence the strangeness of it all. But thank you so much for all of the great tips, I will definitely head back to the printer and reprint the case without using a raft because it is very beautiful :) I have little choice in the material because this printer is the only one the school actually lets students use for fun, but even if the iPod doesn't fit into the case, I still think it will be a pretty display! Thank you so much again for being so helpful to a newbie like me and design/print on! :D

Miniture Piston Keychain has been modeled to have very low clean up required by adding supports & radii. I also separated the bigend to aid printing plus I think the little bolts give it a cool mechanical feel. Parts Required:
1) 2x M3 x 10mm socket head cap screws.
2) 2x M3 nuts. All should be available from a hardware store or fastening supply store.

Print the Piston Body, Conrod & Bigend with the following settings: Infill 100%
Layer Height 0.2mm
Number of shells 1
Feedrate 40 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 80 mm/s
Print Temprature 230c Printed the Roll Pin with the following settings: Infill 100%
Layer Height 0.1mm
Number of shells 0
Feedrate 40 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 80 mm/s
Print Temprature 230c Assembly: 1) Simply assemble the conrod bigend using the M3 nuts & bolts refering to the photos as a guide. The bolt holes shouldn't need reaming as they are slightly oversized.
2) Ream out the piston body & smallend slightly with your 3mm hex key.
3) Pop the smallend of the conrod into the piston body making sure the holes line up.
4) Push the roll pin into the piston body as far as you can by hand.
5) Use a pin punch to carefully tap the roll pin into it's recess. Enjoy!

title: Replacement Button for Wacom Intuos 3 Stylus / Pen

This is a simple case that I made for my KK2.1 board. It may fit other KK boards Like the 2.1.5 This case doesn't fit the 2.0 at this time. If there is enough interest I may mod it to fit the 2.0 also.

First thing I would say is that this case needs to be printed nicely so that it snaps together. I printed this on a flashforge creator X Pro at .2mm layer height in ABS. If your printer is not tuned as nicely as my printer you may have to scale the upper case a little to get it to fit. Once snapped in place it is easiest to open by prying it apart with a knife.  
When you assemble it I would put foam tape or servo tape on the board to act as cushioning spacers on the board. Then I use servo tape or foam tape to attach the case to your quadcopter.

title: T800 Smooth Terminator Endoskull Printable WithBase (not ExoSkull)

description.text:
Please note the file slices nicely with Cura. Some of you folks have had problems in Simplify3D - please try using Cura and you should get some great results.
Thank you for all of you sharing your great prints!

Thank  you azurial for pointing out that we named it exoskull when it's an endoskull. Frankly it's almost embarrassing that we dropped the brain as such... Thank you for the nice comment as well; much appreciated.
EDIT - July 2015

We also uploaded a Terminator Genisys model:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:932640 EDIT - Nov 2014
It's here: the super clean, fast to print, no-supports-required T800.

Download version 5.4.5 !
======================
After hours and hours and hours of clean-up and adjustment work, this is a fairly definitive T800 model that will scale well - it prints wonderfully at 50% scale, 75% scale or 100%scale.
It will slice with Slic3r, Cura, Simply3D, KISSlicer, etc - every slicer we threw at it did a wonderful job.
All the little overhangs are handled (such as eye sockets, cheek bones, nose, side "robot" details, actuators are beefed up, cheek actuators beefed up and adjusted for higher quality/cleaner printing.
Print it fast, print it small, print it big, this is a great model.
A big thanks to all who have worked on this model before it got in our hand - Geoffro, ToScH, MUCKYCHRIS all the way to Landru.
It's amazing how many hands this model has been through to get here. Thanks to all and enjoy.
Use version 5.4.5 !
Original Upload

The T800 model is such a nice one to display on your desk, but it needed a suitable base. Thus, our Chris set on a task of making the model easier to print and give it a base suitable for such an iconic model. There were a few issues with the other model - the jaw would come off the printbed when printing in fine quality, thus there are removable supports built into the model. Secondly, there wasn't much of footprint to touch the bed for such a large model.
It's not an inexpensive model to print, but it attracts lots of attention and it is a great conversation piece.
All models printed on Machina Corp X20 and X24 3D Printers, with Natureworks filament from Ultimachine and ColorFabb.
Enjoy.

comments.text:
It looks like the STL file contains triangles making up about 35 objects. The skull is about 130k triangles and has a few holes. The base is about 20k triangles and possibly complete. There are over 30 spheres and pipe objects that make the tendons, all possibly complete.
Multiple overlapping objects isn't kind to slicers because slicing a level will produce multiple overlapping polygons that then need to be unioned together. Holes in objects make life worse, with the slicer having to guess and close the polygon.
To make this file kind to slicers needs these steps
Detect and extract the 35 objects from 160k unsorted triangles
Repair the skull
Boolean union all 35 objects into one object (one external shell)
but this isn't trivial
comments.author: toddsplod67

comments.text: Hi Toddsplod67
comments.author: toddsplod67

comments.text: Your model is fantastic. Thanks for uploading. I've extracted the parts and have repaired the skull. If I can union it all into one shell I'll share it.
comments.author: machina

comments.text: Well perhaps I should clarify. When a vertex of a triangle lies on the line between the two other vertices, it's not a triangle. This then looks like a hole because it's removal stops the three triangles adjoining it having perfect matching edges (two triangles will sit against one edge of a third triangle). In order to repair, a piece of software would need to cut the third triangle so it matches the first two. Then it can build up triangles into a body by matching edges with edges. This is made harder when triangles don't have an outward normal. It looks like too many problems for Netfabb to handle.
comments.author: toddsplod67

comments.text: I agree with ChuckNorr15. This file has over 200 malformed triangles (3 vertices that don't form a triangle). Many triangles share edges with other triangles but the edge direction isn't opposed which indicates some triangles are facing inwards not outwards. There are holes. I tried NetFabb repair but all it did was drop the malformed triangles. It didn't repair anything else.
comments.author: toddsplod67

description.text:
The collection of the Motor- and Idler Pulley -Brackets is completed. This is the last piece of the puzzle. The goal of the X-Motor Bracket is to reduce the X-Wobble. Update 22 Jan, 2013:
The X-MotorBracketV2 is 42x42x38mm (the first one is 44x44x38). Update 23 Jan, 2013:
X-MotorBracketV3 has a second "cut out" in order to hide the motor wiring. Updade 24 Jan, 2013:
An alternative solution as fma proposed.

Using the X-Motor Bracket V3 you can mount the motor with the wiring on the bottom and conduct the wiring thru the cut out to the top one.
Update 24 Jan, 2013

title: Picoprojector ceiling mount, Z adjustable | laser+3D

description.text:
This small platform can be used to mount a picoprojector to your ceiling.
Z is adjustable.
This plateform was created originaly for a Dell M110 (300Lumens) but could work with any picoprojector < 120mm large...
It's based on 3 lasercuted wood plates and some 3D printed addons.
It's super fast to print and build.

The gear ajust Z, the gear is just a Wade extruder gear (and added for fun ) Building instructions:
*Cut:
-2x Zborder
-1x Border4X
-1x XOrientation Plate
-1x Yplate *Print:
-2x Zbarholder
-1x NutHolder
-1x XOrientationbarholder It use M4 and M5 bolts and M8 bar to change the Z axis orientation of your projector.

description.text:
This rubber band powered mini catapult is only about 10cm long, but it packs a punch! I used a super-strong rubber band that allowed me to launch items up to 1.5 cubic centimeters about ten feet across the room. The catapult's power is dependent on the strength of your rubber band and how far you pull it back. Be sure to look at these accessories by alex80it http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865607
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865653

I would recommend printing both files at 200 micron layer height and with at least 20% infill. No supports are needed if your printer can bridge a 1 cm gap. Most printers can easily do this.
Once printed, turn the lever assembly on it's side and slide it through the base. Snap the pegs of the lever into the base and test to make sure the lever moves up and down.
Slide a rubber band of about 5cm in diameter when relaxed over the spoon of the lever. In the lever there is a small cutout. Push the rubber band into this cutout. From there, pull the rubber band over the tower of the base, allowing it to rest on the small bridge. Continue pulling it to the base, pushing one side into each of the cutouts in the base. Pull the rubber band so that it rests behind the tower. See the picture for a visual.
The catapult is a little fragile, so be careful. Never aim at people or animals, even as a joke. Print and play at your own risk.

title: Ticket To Ride Tray for Small Printer

description.text:
My Printrbot has a small bed -- 100mm x 100mm x 100mm, so I couldn't print the original tray. This has been separated into two trays -- one with three columns and one with two columns, instead of one tray with five columns.
I cut the original with netfabb basic, but it doesn't allow merging parts (that I could find) without paying for the pro version, so I just positioned the "right side" STL on my bed so it's adjacent to the 2- or 3-column piece, merging them for the print. If someone wants to put them together for me, I'd appreciate it.

comments.text: Hi. For 'merging' STL-files you can use Tinkercad.com just import both files and align them. Export as one STL.
comments.author: moga

author: Rhindon

description.text:
I have been using adhesive backed LED strips to light up my print bed on my Makerfarm Prusa i3v 8" printer but the adhesive failed and the strips fell into my print.
I wanted to design a clip on, light weight tray to glue the LED strips down firmly, without having to glue them directly to my carriage frame.
Behold, the finished product!
Here are the strip leds I am using.
(http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002Q907EW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) This design is not compatible with auto bed leveling systems but the left side of this design has been remixed by user dm303102 for compatibility with auto bed leveling, leaving space for a servo. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:581876 UPDATE 11/24/2014
As of today, this part is confirmed to be compatible with clough42's Improved Hexagon Cooling Shroud system: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335613

This add on is printed in 3 pieces and you simply glue them together, with the back slotting on to the top of the left and right side grooves.
Next, cut and glue your LEDs on, then loosen the screws on the left and right side of your x carriage, press them on to the screw shafts, and tighten the screws back down. I recommend printing this part in ABS due to it's proximity to the hotend. User voodoo28 reported that his PLA printed version started melting while printing a different ABS print. Melting will not occur with ABS. Enjoy!

comments.text:
Worked fine...but started warping and dropping after a 5hr abs print at 230 degrees..printed with pla.
Perhaps abs will hold up better. Cool design though!
comments.author: voodoo28

comments.text: Thanks voodoo28. I definitely did not expect that this melting could happen. I printed it in ABS but I didn't think it would be close enough to melt if printed out of PLA. I'll update the instructions to recommend printing in ABS instead. Thanks for this feedback!
comments.author: voodoo28

A box with rounded corners and lid. Many parameters can be adjusted in the .scad file included.

Small box pictured is printed with the value in the included .scad file, except that $fa=10. Both boxes printed with 2 shells, layer height 0.27 mm and 5% infill.
Both the box and lid can be a bit hard to remove from baseplate as they have a huge contact area. This especially goes for large boxes.
Note that roundness must be higher than thickness.

comments.text:
Good design and relatively easy to use.
Any thoughts on smoothing the rounded edges a bit more? I'm looking for a near fully squared edge and with the lack of comments in the code I'm trying to figure out the method to the madness and your help will be appreciated.

Prints without support.

Mount your DK2 camera without a tripod.  Allows you to adjust the camera height and also holds the cables in place.  The piece is designed so that you can print one for the camera, and then one or two more depending on whether you want to screw the base onto something or make a clamp.  See the instructions tab for more information.

Parts:
1) 5/16" dowel
2) 1 bolt with 1/4-20 thread for the camera screw mount
3) optional 8-32x1/2 bolt to hold the dowel.
4) optional screws/bolts to mount the base or make a clamp (see pictures) Print with ABS for maximum flexibility on the cable holders, but should work with PLA, too. This is designed so that you should not need the optional dowel holding bolt (everything should be slightly snug), but your mileage may vary. Depending on how you plan to mount the dowel, you will need to print at least one instance of this part for the camera. If you want to make a clamp, then print 3 total, and if you want to screw the base to a piece of wood, print 2 total. See the pictures for examples.

remixed_from.title: Robo3D Y-axis smooth rod upgrade for stock bed

title: Robo3D Y-axis smooth rod upgrade for stock bed REMIX

description.text:
User reported design works with KickStarter version.
Get $30 worth of parts upgrade of your bed without buying $110 upgrade kit.
!!! BONUS !!!
Moving the Y-End Switch back by 5-7mm will give your bed 270mm motion instead of 250. Almost 20mm more print space for free :)
May have to drill bed mount to allow smooth rods to be inserted.
!!! EXTRA !!!
Print "330mm Y Axis.STL" to get 330mm on Y Axis.
This print will require two 470mm long smooth rods.
!!! ALSO !!!
BedMount Y Motor on the left.STL is for those who want to relocate the Y motor to the left. Read instructions on that.
Print bed mounts with PLA on cold bed on blue M3 painters tape #2090 (See tape roll inner side for the number) at VERY SLOW speed ! This will prevent warping

2 x 8 x 400 mm rods (for standard upgrade)
4 x LM8UU bearings
Reuse rail mount screws to attach bottom bearing housing to the platform.
Reuse remaining screws to attach upper bearing housing.
This is a work in progress, some screws may need to be replaced with others or cut shorter etc. Use what ever works.

If you want to get 330mm on Y Axis, print "330mm Y Axis files"
You would also need to have 470mm long smooth rods as well as a longer belt. About 500mm long should be fine (i guess)

BedMount Y Motor on the left.STL
Need to drill the base for matching holes for the motor to be relocated (obviously)
May required longer belt. If you lucky, old one will work
Y Motor needs to be plugged in in reverse to the board.
Y End Stop switch may need to be relocated.
This mount has no hole for screw to adjust Y End switch distance, so get it as close as possible before securing.

You will need to reflash ROBO3D Firmware and specify new dimensions.
Under Configurations.h look for this line
// Travel limits after homing
Change #define Y_MAX_POS 250 to 270

comments.text: I tried printing this for a Robo R1 +Plus and the rod spacing appears to be too wide for the stock bearing block holes.  My guess is your spacing is 235mm center to center and it looks like mine is 225mm center to center.
comments.author: WZ9V

comments.text:
this was not for R1+, but for older stock bed on drawer rails.
I guess you can drill holes 10mm away to match it.
should not be that difficult to accomplish.
comments.author: WZ9V

comments.text: Thanks, thought that might be the situation.  I plan to borrow your thoughts when laying out some for my printer.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: I printed the lower bearing holders and I check the fit.  I would have to use a vice to push the bearing into the grove.  Is something wrong?  Should it be that tight a fit?
comments.author: wdsparrow

comments.text:
Depends on how you printed.If you printed at regular speed and with stock bed then you may have had slight overlap causing it to go in hard.
Try trimming the edges with a blade or something. It will go in easier.
Part was designed with some slack exactly for that reason. Once upper cover goes on top, it presses it in place in case its printed rather loose then too tight.
Nothing to worry about. If you printed slow (20-30 mm/s) then it should be fine.
The most critical part to print are the bed mounts. Those need to be printed really slow (20mm/s) and with good cooling to prevent warping. (if printed in PLA)
If you print in ABS, then good luck fighting the warp and shrink effect.
cheers
comments.author: wdsparrow

comments.text: Thank for the reply.  I printed using PLA exactly to your spec (cold and slow) but the parts have all come out warped. I'm giving a couple of other settings a try and I'll let you know how it turns out.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text:
If printing slow as i suggested was warped then you had cooling issue.
Perhaps bed heat was used, or cooing fan was not on.
Print on cold bed and cooling on max.
Additional cooling might help if your room temp is high.
comments.author: wdsparrow

comments.text: Interestingly enough after 6 failed prints low and slow, with significant warping, I decided to try stock settings with the only difference being the extruder temperature for the E3D v6 hotend.  The parts completed printing without warping (the bearing parts), first try on each and barely fit.  The fit it a little too snug for real world use.  I would recommend altering the design to give a touch more margin to play with.  I tried printing the frame ends and after 3 failed prints (not warping, my download may have been corrupted because at exactly the same height each time the print shifts by a 1/2 centimeter).  I may have to go back to the original design.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text:
Am not sure what you mean with low and slow. You need slow speed print about 30mm/s and maximum cooling with normal temperatures that are "normal" to your hot end.
Little too snug is not a bad thing, it will help get things in a perfect alignment. If in your case it is tighter and in my case its more loose then my design has nailed it in the head making sure it will work for people who print it tight and for people who print it loose.
comments.author: wdsparrow

comments.text: Do your bearing holders mount to the same holes on the robo3d?
comments.author: sal42na68

comments.text:
Yes
If you want to get it right the first time, do this.
Print with PLA
Print with 20-30mm/s, no faster.
No heat bed.
If you have adhering problems, use blue 3M painters tape (tne original and the best). It works best on cold bed.
Cooling fans on max.
Slow print speed and no heat on the bed and max cooling will create solid model with no warping.
Warping will ruin everything, so dont even try to go with ABS.
comments.author: sal42na68

comments.text: This picture explains a lot about under the bed. Cool man. I am interested to know what software you would recomend to a new designer. You know what you are doing. Can you put a longer bed on that thing easily, if you get longer rods, belt, and wire?

I would however recommend to extend bearing housing support to provide more attachment surface area. It should work no problem.

description.text: Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please. If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

description.text:
Because Recycling is not just to help the planet, It also helps our pocket.
This is the first object of a series dedicated to the blending of DIY3DPrinting and R3 (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle). There is a new version, tested and working. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:723575

This model is suited for a baby food pot of about 112 mm height. You must make a hole on the lid by using a 13 mm drill bit for metals. Then screw the threads on the pipe with the lid in the middle. That's it, you just made your own stuff, reduced your ecological footprint, saved some money and of course, sweetened your favorite drink.  
You can find a pipe with a round base to print it upright.  
If you print the based pipe, you should use a blade to cut it off after printing.  
The .rar file contains the .ipt models. If you want to modify something just open the .ipt file, go to parameters and change them (the parameters you have to modify are explained on the file).

description.text:
This is a Gimbal designed for a DIY SteadiCam that I made for a colleague at work (See http://www.yb2normal.com/DIYsteadicam.html). It makes use of two 624 bearings in addition to the required 608 bearing.
It would also be possible to use four 624 bearings or to use no 624 bearings. I thought using two was a good compromise. If you decide to use no 624 bearings then the height of the middle ring can be reduced to 16mm (same as the outer ring) or even 12mm.

First glue the 608 bearing to the center of the Inner ring and the two 624 bearings to their proper location in the Middle ring. Then attach the 4mm cap screw from the outside of the Outer ring to the Middle ring.  On each side of a ring there should be a washer. It should be as follows: cap head, washer, outer ring, washer, nut, nut, washer, 624 bearing, washer and finally the nut.
Now attach the Middle ring to the Inner ring by using 4mm cap screw, washer, middle ring, washer, nut.
Adjust as necessary to get good movement.

description.text:
This is a panel mount that I made in FreeCAD 3D to mount a LED light control to my G-Star Dual 3D printer (MakerBot 2X open source version). It has a solid bottom and a 40mm hole in the back for wiring to pass through. The back is dual skinned so it has structural support to drill through so screws won't easily pull through. The opening in the front is 59mm W x 86mm H. The panel surface is 90mm x 90mm with a 45 degree slant. The sides and framing edges are solid enough to sink wood screws directly into for mounting any control panel onto it. Feel free to modify as needed for anything you want to use it on.
Cheers!
I found this to print well with 2 skins and 10% infill. I used 230 F with PLA on a heated bed set to 60F. That gave me a glossy finish with no warping on the bed contact patch.

Use these hold down clamps on a 150mm deep Makerbot 2X print bed to minimize warping on large parts.  
Just add a .75 to 1 mm pad on the edge of your printed part, and snap these onto the bed once the pads have completed printing.  (Pausing your printer for a minute should help.)  The clamps hold the edges of the print down to minimize warping.  The extra pads can then be snapped off when your print finishes, and quick exposure to the heat from a lighter covers up the snapped edge.  
The dimensions for these clamps are set for my personal Makerbot 2X Chinese knock-off printer, but hopefully they fit most Makerbot aluminum print beds.  
I found it best to print using PLA, 15% density, and 4 outer skin layers.  
The .FUN file is the source for the clamp, developed with Cubify.

title: Galaxy S5 Qi Charging Motorcycle Cradle

description.text: This is a Qi wireless charging cradle that is compatible with the Samsung Galaxy S5's OEM wireless charging back. Designed to work with the RAM EZ-Strap Mount, which utilizes a 3/4" ball socket and a Qi wireless charging DIY kit from Ebay/Amazon. Completely printed but not yet mounted on motorcycle for testing, but ball socket joint seems to be real secure and phone stays put. Inspired by tactic's bike mount, modified to work without the charging case and just the charging back. Uses my own 3/4" ball mount but could be used with 3daybreaker's Ram compatible Look-a-Like mounting system, just use that ball and necessary hardware.

Printed all 3 pieces at .2 mm layer height, 40% infill for ball, 20% infill for base and holder. Once printed tap ball with 5mm tap and use 5mm screw and nut captured in ball to connect to base. Insert Qi DIY kit into holder and slide into base. Superglue/Vapor weld parts together for final water resistance (hopefully). Note: the Qi PCBA used in this project was purchased from ebay and included both a micro usb break out board with pigtail wiring and micro usb port directly on board.

title: Hummingbird Feeder Ant Moat  with Solidworks 2014 Source.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The ants were so bad this year that I had to do something. I went out to see why my hummingbirds had been mia for 2 days when I had just cleaned, and refilled, the feeder only to see a dead ant floating inside the feeder. I looked closer and there was an ant trail going to it. When I grabbed it and flipped it over about 30 dead ants went floating to the top with another 20, or so, dead ones trapped in the inner part.
So, I grabbed a 13 gauge wire hanger and printed this. The hole is 2.1mm so made for a 13 gauge wire coat hanger but you could use anything you wish just be sure it will not rust.
Hummingbird_Feeder_Ant_Moat-2.sldprt is with the center being hollow. The stl is of Hummingbird_Feeder_Ant_Moat.sldprt
I have added a size reduced model, with source, that will print much much faster.

Moat goes above the feeder so mount->moat->feeder and you fill the moat with water.  This was designed to conserve water so it takes very little to fill it but make sure you only fill it up to about 2mm from the lip in case the ants decide to commit suicide to form a bridge for the rest of the colony to cross over (trust me they do these things for the greater good of the colony).

remixed_from.author: Frugalshave
remixed_from.title: 1" Diameter Knurled Knob for 1/4x20 nuts and bolts

description.text: I really liked the 1in Diameter Knurled Knob, but wanted something that could be customized on a per project basis. So I grabbed the Knurled surface finishing library and sprinkled in a little bit of my newbie OpenSCAD skills to create this simple parametric knurled knob. The first use I had for this part was to add a knob to the outside hex nut on the Low friction spool holder. Since I wanted a way to quickly tighten down the nut if it ever came loose. This is my first OpenSCAD model, so if you have any tips on making this thing better please leave them in the Comments section.

• Download OpenSCAD (www.openscad.org)
  • Download the knurledFinishLib.scad as well as the knurled_nut_knob.scad file provided and place them in the same directory.
  • Now open the knurled_nut_knob.scad file in OpenSCAD
  • Customize the values in the Parameters section
  • Choose Design -> Compile and Render
  • Choose File -> Export -> Export as STL
    • Now you have a STL file you can use with your particular setup.

description.text:
This is a plant cell printed in several colors in one go. Look at the film to understand how printing was done and read Instructions part. I used it as a first models when I created time lapse film for colorFabb's summer 2014 challenge which as a matter of fact took the 1st prize!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqIiJflavg0 Here is original Sketchup that I used: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=75d7fcd3b6e457781237a5ac6a4e5f67

I have edited original model from Sketchup Warehouse and split it into parts hanging one over the other (in Sketchup). Then I exported each part or collection of parts into a STL file.
STL files are therefore hanging in the air except base1 which is the first one to be printed and it is laying on the bottom plate.
There is a tiny circle in each model on the corners which I used as a guide point, don't worry it will not be printed but will be used by slicer as a reference to the bottom plate. I printed on Ultimaker2 and these instructions are based on it and Cura as a slicer.
  • In Cura's Expert Settings set Skirt parameter to 0

  • Download all STL files and print the order described below. When the first part is finished do not remove or move it, just change the filament to another color and continue with the next part. Look at the picture to know which color to choose noting that there are several parts that should be of the same color.

  • Start printing in this order
    Base1.stl
    Base2.stl
    1.stl
    2.stl
    3.stl
    4.stl
    5.stl
    6.stl
    7.stl
    • All other files are for you reference and use , you do not need to print them.

description.text: I got so excited about the first print from my new MakerBot (a 20 mm cube) that I decided I wanted to make a stand for it. After some experimentation with the OpenSCAD and ReplicatorG software, I came up with this. It was the second thing I printed out on the MakerBot, and it looks pretty decent. I\'m going to print out a Glow-in-the-dark cube to stick in it when my new plastic arrives.

You should be able to open, render, and export it in OpenSCAD. It's not truly parametric, but there are enough useful variables that, with some tweaking, changing the design (and especially the object it's able to hold up) should be fairly simple.

title: Firefighter Wedge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad, but you can design your own in the Customizer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93859



We use wedges like these to block open doors like a doorstop or at the hinge. Two wedges can be pushed together inside the frame of a sprinkler head to shut off the (copious) flow of water. Not sure if ABS is up to the stresses of closing a sprinkler head - I guess I will have to test. Print it in a bright color so that you don't lose it on the fireground.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

The observant reader will notice that I didn't print this in a bright color...
Also, the narrow tip of this object curled upwards a bit, maybe from when I pried it off the Kapton, but it may have been curled before. I made another version with less of a point and it curled less. I have much to learn, but this came out well.
I find watching the lattice of interior fill get printed fascinating. Stay safe!

We use these to protect the threads of SCBA (firefighting air packs) bottles during storage and transport. They are a cheap little plastic cap that costs nothing. title: Toyota Prius Wheel Center Cap - ZAP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. If you have a Generation III Prius (2010-present), you can pop off the UGLY wheel covers to release the alloy beasts underneath. Except - you'll have a hole in the center of the wheel that begs for a decorative cap. This is precisely measured from the Toyota part number 42603-52110 (pictured). This has a stylized lightning bolt embossed in the top of the wheel cover. Also fits Yaris, Vios These and other center cap designs are available through Shapeways: http://www.shapeways.com/shops/bitforge?section=Prius+Wheel+Center+Caps&s=0

I'm not sure how these WILL print - I am sure that they will need support.  Experimentation is in order. The dimensions are as accurate from the original part as I could get, but the diameter may need to be squidged a bit for a proper snug fit. Disclaimer- you print and use this part at your own risk.

comments.text: Way cool, if the test one sizes up well my Prius will be sporting new centers by tomorrow afternoon.

author: schlem

description.text:
A snug-fit casing for your gopro!
Protects the camera without the heavy waterproof case.
Ideal for mounting to UAVs, 3D printers, bikes and more!

• 3mm thick plywood (any grade)
  • medium or thick CA
  • CA accelerator (like Zip Kicker)
  • wide masking tape
• Laser cutter (our settings: 12mm/s at 25W)

• Install masking tape on top of the cut area of plywood. This prevents scorching.
  • Laser cut the 5 side pieces.
  • Fit the pieces together.
  • Insert the gopro into the dryfit casing.
  • Drop some glue onto the top of each slotted joint, allowing the glue to seep into the joints.
  • Gently slide the gopro out of the casing.
  • Blast accelerator over the glued joints; one spray per side is plenty.
    • For a better looking case, you can sand and paint the outside before laser cutting!
